Graphical abstract Sandwich–like NiFe layered double hydroxides/Co1-xS (NiFe LDH/Co1-xS) heterostructure with synergistic electrocatalytic effects for highly efficient oxygen evolution reaction is successfully prepared by electrodepositing Co1-xS on the surface of NiFe LDH grown on nickel foam (NF). The NF supported heterostructure possesses three-dimensional (3D) catalytic space and strained heterointerface. Thereinto the Co1-xS layer provides extra active sites over the original NiFe LDH. Besides, the lattice mismatch in the surface of NiFe LDH induces the formation of lattice strain in Co1-xS, which thus modulates the local electronic structures. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations validate that the strained heterointerface has advantageous OER activity. From the results of electrochemical tests, the NiFe LDH/Co1-xS possesses large number of active sites and fast charge transfer. More importantly, optimized structure and interface characteristics improve the electrocatalytic stability, resulting in long–term durability with almost no attenuation after 150 h constant current test. Keywords NiFe layered double hydroxides Co1-xS Sandwich–like Oxygen evolution reaction Long–term durability 1 Introduction Electrochemical water splitting is considered as one of the most promising green technologies for energy conversion and storage, which realizes the conversion of electric energy to chemical energy and can be easily combined with other clean energy resources [1–3]. Water electrolysis includes two half reactions: the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [4–6]. Due to higher overpotential, the OER process has been considered as the bottleneck in overall water splitting [7–11]. Therefore, the sluggish kinetics in water oxidation requires efficient catalysts to reduce the overpotential. At present, the state‐of‐the‐art catalytic materials are Ir and Ru based oxides (such as IrO2 and RuO2). However, the scarcity of Ir and Ru elements limits their wide applications [12–15]. To cater for these challenges, considerable efforts have been devoted in recent years to design and develop non–precious metal–based electrocatalysts [16,17]. Among the numerous potential electrocatalysts, layered double hydroxides (LDH) have attracted more attention owing to their tunable chemical component and unique electronic structure [18,19]. However, the bulk LDH usually does not possess good OER performance majorly because of less active site. Therefore, recent studies often involve the fabrication of defects on LDH electrocatalysts or compositing them with other components. For example, by the confined growth of both NiFe–LDH and carbon in one single sheet, amorphous NiFe–LDH/C nanohybrid was obtained, which exhibited superior activity due to the enhanced active surface area and strong coupling property between the amorphous carbon and the NiFe–LDH [20]. Moreover, exfoliating bulk CoFe LDHs into ultrathin 2D LDH nanosheets through Ar plasma etching resulted in the formation of multiple vacancies (including O, Co, and Fe vacancies), which consequently brought more active sites [13]. Also due to the two dimensional characteristics, ultrafine NiFe–LDH nanosheets possessed abundant metal and oxygen vacancies, imparting superior charge transfer property and electrochemical water oxidation performance [21]. Nevertheless, most of the above mentioned improvement strategies involve complex preparation processes and severe experimental conditions, which are not practical for large–scale promotion. Moreover, in comparison to upgrading the activity, the improvement of OER stability is relatively neglected. The surfaces of LDH are easily corroded and destroyed, which reduce the catalytic stability seriously. Actually, only the edges of LDH provide the major active sites, a large number of surfaces are nearly paralyzed [22,23]. On the other hand, the surfaces of LDH are easily corroded and destroyed, which reduce the catalytic stability seriously. Therefore, rational utilization of structural specialty to promote the LDH to own both long–term durability and high activity has become a hot research topic. Cobalt sulfur compounds have been extensively studied as electrocatalysts for OER, but their large charge transfer resistances reduce the activity [24–28]. As suggested by some related researches, heterostructure can modulate the electronic arrangement to promote the charge conduction [29–31]. Herein, sandwich–like NiFe LDH/Co1-xS was prepared by constant potential electrodeposition of Co1-xS on the surface of NiFe LDH grown on Ni foam in only 25 s. The surface of LDH was completely covered in the solution reaction system (mixed Co2+ and S source), indicating the full utilization of the reaction space. NiFe LDH/Co1-xS was composed of one layer of NiFe LDH and two layers of Co1-xS, and Co1-xS grew on both sides of NiFe LDH. In such a heterostructure, Co1-xS provided additional active phases [32,33]. Meanwhile, the lattice mismatch in the surface of NiFe LDH made the electrodeposited Co1-xS has a great amount of strained interfaces, which rearranged the local electron structures to promote the transmission efficiency of charge and the chemisorption of oxygen–containing intermediates. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations showed that the compressive strain possesses lower free energy in OER, confirming the advantages of the heterostructure. As expected, NiFe LDH/Co1-xS afforded high catalytic OER activity with an overpotential of 251 mV at 10 mA·cm−2 in an alkaline electrolyte. The value of the electrochemical surface area is 32.84 mF·cm−2, much larger than the sum of pure NiFe LDH (5.49 mF·cm−2) and Co1-xS (17.98 mF·cm−2). Tafel slope and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy reveal a favorable kinetic during electrolysis. Especially, benefiting from the optimized structure and interface characteristics, NiFe LDH/Co1-xS exhibited excellent stability over 150 h of continuous operation. It was believed that the facile synthesis strategy and strained interface engineering of the sandwich–like heterostructure could be extended to prepare other cost–efficient electrocatalysts for various applications. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material The electrolytic cell and electrodes were all purchased from the Tianjin ida Hengsheng Technology Development Limited Company. The electrolytic cell was composed of Teflon cover and glass tank body, which had 150 mL volume. The model of the saturated calomel electrode was RO217 with the upper diameter was 9 mm, the lower diameter was 5 mm and the full length was 140 mm. The model of the carbon rod electrode was C105 with the spectroscopic pure graphite of 5 mm diameter. The arrangement of the electrodes was equilateral triangle. And the distance among them (reference, counter electrode and working electrodes) were all 1 cm. 2.2 Preparation of NiFe LDH, Co1-xS and NiFe LDH/Co1-xS Typically, a piece (1 cm × n cm, n > 1) of nickel foam (NF) was washed in water, ethanol, acetone, 1 M HCl solution and water in turn to ensure that all residual organic species were removed prior to preparation. The NiFe LDH/Co1-xS electrodes were prepared by a simple two‐step hydrothermal–electrodeposition method. Firstly, the pure NiFe LDH was generated by using a hydrothermal treatment at 120 °C for 12 h. The reaction system consisted of 0.29 g nickel nitrate, 0.40 g ferric nitrate, 0.45 g urea and 0.15 g ammonium fluoride. Secondly, the Co1-xS was electrodeposited on the surface of NiFe LDH through the constant potential electrodeposition method (the potential is −1.4 V) in the mixture of cobalt nitrate (0.73 g), thiourea (1.91 g) and 100 mL deionized water for only 25 s. The NiFe LDH/Co1-xS electrodes could be achieved by rinsing the NF with ethanol and water after deposition, as well as drying at 60 °C for a short time. NiFe LDH and Co1-xS were prepared by using the same method in the first and second step, respectively. 2.3 Material characterizations The crystallographic phases of various samples were acquired by using X–ray diffraction (XRD) technology on a Rigaku Ultima III diffractometer with Cu Ka radiation (λ = 0.154178 nm). The scanning range was 10–70° and the scan rate was 6° min−1. The morphologies of various samples were observed by using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, FEI Nova NanoSEM 230) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOL JEM–2100). X–ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, PHI 5000 Versa Probe UlVAC–PHI) was used to acquire the elemental bonding configuration and surface chemical composition of the samples, with an Al Kα X–ray radiation and a reference of C 1s (binding energy of 284.5 eV). 2.4 Electrochemical measurements All electrochemical activities were evaluated using a typical three–electrode configuration with a CHI660E electrochemical workstation analyzer in 1 M KOH electrolyte. The reference was a saturated calomel electrode, the counter electrode was carbon rod and the working electrodes were as–synthesized various electrocatalysts. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) for OER were performed with a scan rate of 2 mV·s−1. The long–term electrochemical stability was performed using constant current measurements of 10 mA·cm−2. The double–layer capacitances (Cdl) of the samples were measured via a simple cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurement to indicate the electrochemically active surface areas (ECSA) in the region from 0.12 to 0.22 V versus the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were recorded at 0.42 V with a frequency range from 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz. All potentials reported in this work were converted to the corresponding potentials versus the RHE using the following equation: ERHE = ESCE + 0.244 + 0.0591 × pH where ERHE and ESCE are the potentials versus RHE and the measured potentials versus calomel reference electrode, respectively. 2.5 Density functional theory (DFT) computational details DFT calculations were done using the projector-augmented wave method and a plane-wave basis set as implemented in the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP). The valence configurations were treated as 1 s1 for H, 2s22p4 for O, 3s23p4 for S, 3d84s1 for Co, and 3d94s1 for Ni. The Bayesian Error Estimation Functional with van der Waals correlation (BEEF–vdW) was employed. The cutoff energy for plane-wave basis functions was 550 eV. The detailed calculation parameters and process can be found in Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion Catalysts grew directly on the surface of nickel foam (NF), which provided sufficient mechanical strength and conductivity and avoided the usage of binder additives [34,35]. Specifically, the NiFe LDH/Co1-xS electrodes were prepared by a simple two‐step hydrothermal–electrodeposition method, which was briefly schematically illustrated in Fig. 1 . NiFe LDH was generated in the first hydrothermal reaction at 120 °C for 12 h. In the second step, the Co1-xS was electrodeposited on the surface of NiFe LDH through the constant potential electrodeposition method in the mixture of Co2+ and S source for only 25 s. The X‐ray diffraction (XRD) spectrum of the as–prepared NiFe LDH/Co1-xS was shown in Fig. 2 , together with that of the bare NiFe LDH as reference for interpreting the structure information. For the pattern of NiFe LDH, the peaks located at 2θ = 44.5° and 51.9° could be assigned to the (1 1 1) and (2 0 0) planes of Ni substrate, respectively (PDF#04‐0850) [36,37]. The (0 0 3), (0 0 6), (0 1 2) and (0 1 5) planes well matched the crystalline phase of NiFe LDH (PDF#40‐0215) (Fig. S1 in Supporting Information) [38,39]. For bare Co1-xS (Fig. S2), it was hard to find the correlation XRD peaks due to its low crystallinity. But for NiFe LDH/Co1-xS, the relative intensity of the peak at 2θ = 34.4° (corresponding to the surface crystal plane) decreased remarkably, illustrating a large amount of Co1-xS growing on the surface of NiFe LDH, which reduced the exposure of NiFe LDH surface crystal plane. Fig. 3 showed the morphologies of various samples observed by the scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The SEM image of Co1-xS presented a large amount of nanosheets, which looked like the skin of coral (Fig. 3a). The EDX pattern shown in Fig. S3 confirmed the presence of Co and S and the ratio for Co:S of 2.65:3.07. NiFe LDH also displayed a sheet-like structure but with a larger size (Fig. 3b), which was beneficial to act as the conductive substrate. The Co1-xS and NiFe LDH both contacted to the NF directly, building up direct electron transportation path between the catalysts and current collector, hence decreasing the contact resistance and ensuring effective participation of them in the electrochemical reactions [40–42]. Whereas for NiFe LDH/Co1-xS (Fig. 3c and d), it could be easily found that the surfaces of NiFe LDH were almost entirely covered by the electrodeposited Co1-xS except the edges of the nanosheets. In other words, the facile synthesis strategy acquired the distinctive sandwich–like heterostructure, which inclined to increase the utilization of the limited catalytic space. Fig. 3e–i, S4 and S5 presented the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of various samples detached ultrasonically from the NF substrate to further investigate the morphology as well as the interfaces between the NiFe LDH and Co1-xS nanosheets. Co1-xS and NiFe LDH exhibited two different micromorphological characteristics. For example, Co1-xS had a large amount of wrinkles (Fig. S4a), whereas NiFe LDH showed much smoother surfaces (Fig. S5a). The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns and the HRTEM images revealed the crystal face orientations of Co1-xS (Fig. S4b and S4c) and NiFe LDH (Fig. S5b and S5c), respectively. The electrodeposited Co1-xS presented low crystallinity, which coincided well with the results of XRD patterns in Fig. 2 and S2. In Fig. S4d, the line scan spans 4 atomic layers and covers 0.765 nm in length, showing the interplanar spacing of 0.1913 nm for Co1-xS (1 0 2) [43]. For NiFe LDH, the line scan spans 5 atomic layers and covers 1.238 nm in length, showing the interplanar spacing of 0.2476 nm for the (0 1 2) crystal plane [44]. The heterojunction catalyst possessed both structures of Co1-xS and NiFe LDH (Fig. 3e). Co1-xS nanosheets grew on the surface of NiFe LDH. Two kinds of diffraction fringes in the SAED pattern of NiFe LDH/Co1-xS (Fig. 3f) could be identified, which concretely confirmed the heterostructure. The HRTEM image also exhibited the interface between NiFe LDH and Co1-xS (Fig. 3g). Meanwhile, the interplanar spacing of Co1-xS (1 0 2) increased evidently in the heterointerface from 0.1923 nm to 0.1942 nm and was accompanied by a certain degree of bending. This is a result of the lattice mismatch in the surface of NiFe LDH induces the formation of lattice strain in Co1-xS. Thus the NiFe LDH basal stretched the interplanar spacing of Co1-xS, making the formation of the strained heterointerfaces, which were good for modulating the local electronic structures and facilitating charge transportation. X‐ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to investigate the influence of electrodeposited Co1-xS on the surface chemical state and composition of NiFe LDH/Co1-xS. The NiFe LDH and Co1-xS were served as the references, as shown in Fig. 4 . The high‐resolution Ni 2p spectra (Fig. 4a) clearly displayed the Ni2+ and Ni3+ peaks at 855.5 and 857.4 eV, respectively [45,46]. It was obviously to see that the relative quantity of Ni3+ in NiFe LDH/Co1-xS was less than that in NiFe LDH. This could be attributed to the more distribution of Ni3+ on the surface of NiFe LDH nanosheets. Ni3+ originated the oxidation reaction in hydrothermal process. In the reaction system, ammonium fluoride acted as an oxidant in fact. And the reaction environment of high temperature and high pressure accelerated the process of various reactions. So a portion of Ni2+ ions were oxidized to Ni3+ ions to form the mismatched lattices in the surface, which would affect the lattice structure of the electrodeposited Co1-xS [47–50]. The Fe 2p spectra exhibited a relatively stable state (Fig. 4b), suggesting that the chemical environment of iron ion was unchanged by the electrodeposition treatment [51]. As for S 2p spectra, there was almost no difference between NiFe LDH/Co1-xS and Co1-xS (Fig. S6). But for Co 2p3/2, the relative quantity of Co3+ decreased and Co2+ increased significantly in NiFe LDH/Co1-xS (Fig. 4c), which was attributed to lattice mismatch in the surface of NiFe LDH, i.e., the compressive strain interaction had changed the distribution of charge. Meanwhile, after the electrodeposition reaction, the XPS spectra of Ni 2p and Co 2p3/2 in NiFe LDH/Co1-xS show some obvious changes. The proportions of Ni2+ and Co2+ increase in contrast to Ni3+ and Co3+, respectively. Here, the content of low valence metal ions rises, which is less bound to electrons. So, the system of NiFe LDH/Co1-xS is propitious to improvement of charge transfer. Electrochemical measurements were conducted on the catalysts with an area of 1 cm2 to evaluate the OER performance. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was recorded in 1 M KOH solution using a standard three–electrode system, which included a carbon rod counter electrode, a saturated calomel reference electrode, and working electrodes made of the prepared various electrocatalysts, respectively. As shown in the OER polarization curves (Fig. 5 a), NiFe LDH/Co1-xS electrode exhibited a remarkable catalytic activity, which had a lower onset potential than NiFe LDH, Co1-xS and pure NF (Fig. S7). The reverse scan of cyclic voltammetry (CV) curve from positive to negative potential revealed that NiFe LDH/Co1-xS achieved a current density of 10 mA·cm−2 only at an overpotential of 251 mV, indicating a very high energy efficiency for catalyzing OER process. More importantly, the overpotential reduced significantly (Δ ≈ 61 mV) as compared to the bare NiFe LDH (312 mV). As for Co1-xS and NF, their overpotentials were 360 mV and 419 mV at 10 mA·cm−2, respectively, also much higher than that of the heterostructure catalyst. To further highlight the superiority of NiFe LDH/Co1-xS in different current densities, the overpotentials at current densities of 20, 100 and 200 mA·cm−2 were shown in Fig. S8. Tafel slopes of various samples were given in Fig. 5b. The value of 41.67 mV·dec−1 for NiFe LDH/Co1-xS was lower than 60.61 mV·dec−1 for NiFe LDH and 67.80 mV·dec−1 for Co1-xS, implying the favorable OER kinetics for this heterojunction catalyst [52,53]. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis was performed to study the interfacial properties of the electrocatalyst electrodes (Fig. 5c). Apparently, Co1-xS had much higher electron‐transfer resistance than NiFe LDH. Benefiting from the sandwich–like structure and strained heterointerfaces, NiFe LDH/Co1-xS showed the lowest value. In which the mismatched lattices in the surface of NiFe LDH/Co1-xS were easy to interact with the electrodeposited Co1-xS to form strained heterointerfaces, which was propitious to the transfer of electron. Furthermore, due to the electrochemical double layer capacitance (C dl) was proportional to electrochemical active surface area (ECSA), the values of C dl for different electrocatalysts could reflect the differences in ECSA between them. C dl was measured by the CV curves in the proper potential range (0.12 V—0.22 V) without redox processes (Fig. S9). NiFe LDH/Co1-xS electrode had a much larger C dl (32.84 mF·cm−2) than that of NiFe LDH (5.49 mF·cm−2) and Co1-xS (17.98 mF·cm−2) (Fig. S10), suggesting that this heterojunction catalyst had more electrochemical active sites for OER [54,55]. Long–term durability was a crucial criterion to evaluate the electrocatalytic performance of the as–prepared electrodes. When operating the OER at the constant current of 10 mA·cm−2, corresponding potentials were observed on NiFe LDH/Co1-xS, NiFe LDH, Co1-xS and NF electrodes in 1 M KOH. After 15 h of testing, almost no attenuation of potential compared to the initial potential of NiFe LDH/Co1-xS was observed. But, as shown in Fig. 5d, Co1-xS and NiFe LDH could only maintain their initial potentials of 97.02% and 91.63%, respectively. This suggested that the heterojunction catalyst was much more stable than either component under OER conditions. In order to validate the superior durability of NiFe LDH/Co1-xS, a 150 h long–term durability text was carried out in 1 M KOH (Fig. 5e). The increase of overpotential was very small (<3 mV) over such a long–term operation. At high current density of 50 mA·cm−2, NiFe LDH/Co1-xS also had a good stable performance (Fig. S11). Meanwhile, from the polarization curve of NiFe LDH/Co1-xS after the OER stability test, the electrocatalytic activity nearly had no change (Fig. S12), suggesting a very excellent electrocatalytic durability. This convincingly proved that, profiting from the full utilization of catalytic space and strained interface engineering, the sandwich–like heterostructure NiFe LDH/Co1-xS acquired by the proposed facile method exhibited both great activity and stability towards OER process. To better understand the electrochemical OER activity, DFT calculations were carried to construct the free energy diagram for OER over CoS/NiFe LDH in comparison with CoS, Ni-doped CoS and the ideal catalyst (Fig. 6 ). Here, CoS/NiFe LDH denoted CoS with 9% biaxially compressive strain electrodeposited on NiFe LDH. Based on the TEM images in Fig. 3, CoS (1 0 2) terminated with fourfold- and fivefold-coordinated Co atoms was chosen as the active surface for OER. Considering the calculated overpotentials (Table S1), the fivefold-coordinated Co top site rather than the fourfold-coordinated Co-Co bridge site was taken into account as the active site for OER. Adsorption of intermediates OH*, O* and OOH* occurred on the fivefold-coordinated Co top site for CoS, Co0.875Ni0.125S and CoS/NiFe LDH, as shown in Fig. 6a and 6b. For all cases, the formation of the intermediate OOH* was the potential-determining step. The calculated overpotentials were 0.47 V for CoS/NiFe LDH, 0.55 V for NiFe LDH, 0.62 V for Co0.875Ni0.125S, and 0.67 V for CoS (Table S2). As was well known, experimental overpotentials depending on the current density were proportional to the theoretical overpotential [56,57]. Thus, the predicted trends in OER activity on these compounds were in accordance with our experimental results. In a word, our combined experimental and theoretical study indicated that the compressive strain was much better than the Ni doping in boosting the OER activity of CoS electrocatalyst. The result of OER activity for Ni-doped CoS was shown in Fig. S13. The high–resolution XPS profile of NiFe LDH/Co1-xS after the long term stability test was illustrated in Fig. 7 and Fig. S14. The Ni, Fe, Co and S ions still existed in the heterojunction system, which once again proved that the heterostructure was very stable and difficult to be corroded in alkaline media. Specially, Fe 2p and S 2p remained stable chemical states corresponding to the initial structure, illustrating that Fe and S ions were not the major active elements. By contrast, a certain degree of right shift and left shift occurred in Ni 2p and Co 2p3/2, respectively. The values of the shift weer 0.24 eV for Ni2+, 0.4 eV for Ni3+, 1.06 eV for Co3+ and 1.15 eV for Co2+, which could be ascribed to the strong interaction between Ni and Co ions. This again confirmed that the strained heterointerface had a great positive effect to charge transfer. For the XRD pattern of NiFe LDH/Co1-xS-Spent (Fig. S16), it could be find that the relative intensity of (0 1 2) peak increased relative to NiFe LDH/Co1-xS. As shown in Fig. S17, NiFe LDH/Co1-xS only contained a small amount (only 0.83%) of S due to a short electrodeposition reaction. And for NiFe LDH/Co1-xS-Spent, the S content was so small that it was difficult to measure accurately, illustrating the long term stability test arose a certain degree abscission of Co1-xS. But from the TEM and HRTEM images of NiFe LDH/Co1-xS-Spent (Fig. S18), there was no significant change, the strained heterointerface effect would still be stable. This explained the reason why NiFe LDH/Co1-xS had a lasting OER activity even if after a long–term operation. Table S3 compared the activity of NiFe LDH/Co1-xS with recently reported state‐of‐the‐art materials. The NiFe LDH/Co1-xS showed superior catalytic performance than the majority of the reported catalysts. Therefore, considering the potential of LDH in OER, as well as in order to solve its defects in catalytic durability, we use a simple method to prepare sandwich–like heterostructure NiFe LDH/Co1-xS electrocatalyst. NiFe LDH/Co1-xS is composed of one layer of NiFe LDH and two layers of Co1-xS, and Co1-xS grow on both sides of NiFe LDH. A series of tests show that pure NiFe LDH does exhibit poor structure and catalytic stability. While for NiFe LDH/Co1-xS, in addition to improving the OER activity, the stability of it has been greatly improved. We think that in catalytic reaction, the Co1-xS layer provides extra active sites over the original NiFe LDH (as seen in ECSA) and protects the vulnerable surface of LDH (as seen in stability test). And the heterointerface between NiFe LDH and Co1-xS has advantageous for further improving OER activity (as seen in DFT). So, the scheme of structural optimization is simple and effective. In the field of catalysis, stability is a bottleneck, our design and results provide a good idea for obtaining excellent electrocatalysts. 4 Conclusion In summary, sandwich–like heterostructure NiFe LDH/Co1-xS electrode has been successfully prepared on NF through a simple two–step hydrothermal–electrodeposition method. The 3D catalytic space and strained heterointerface effectively promoted the electronic interaction, leading to intensified reaction kinetics and stimulated chemisorption of oxygen–containing intermediates, finally got good activity and stability for OER. The enhanced performance of NiFe LDH/Co1-xS electrode was characterized by a low overpotential of 251 mV at a current density of 10 mA·cm−2. Furthermore, NiFe LDH/Co1-xS achieved a long–term durability in alkaline medium, much better to recently reported earth–abundant electrocatalysts. Profiting from the full utilization of catalytic space and interface engineering, the sandwich–like heterostructure NiFe LDH/Co1-xS acquired by the proposed facile method exhibited both great activity and stability towards OER process. Therefore, the sandwich–like heterostructure NiFe LDH/Co1-xS could be a promising candidate electrocatalyst for water splitting and other electrochemical applications such as CO2 reduction, rechargeable metal–air batteries and N2 reduction. coredata.dc:description: Sandwich–like NiFe layered double hydroxides/Co1-xS (NiFe LDH/Co1-xS) heterostructure with synergistic electrocatalytic effects for highly efficient oxygen evolution reaction is successfully prepared by electrodepositing Co1-xS on the surface of NiFe LDH grown on nickel foam (NF). The NF supported heterostructure possesses three-dimensional (3D) catalytic space and strained heterointerface. Thereinto the Co1-xS layer provides extra active sites over the original NiFe LDH. Besides, the lattice mismatch in the surface of NiFe LDH induces the formation of lattice strain in Co1-xS, which thus modulates the local electronic structures. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations validate that the strained heterointerface has advantageous OER activity. From the results of electrochemical tests, the NiFe LDH/Co1-xS possesses large number of active sites and fast charge transfer. More importantly, optimized structure and interface characteristics improve the electrocatalytic stability, resulting in long–term durability with almost no attenuation after 150 h constant current test.
coredata.dc:title: Strained heterointerfaces in sandwich–like NiFe layered double hydroxides/Co1-xS for highly efficient and superior long–term durable oxygen evolution reaction
